text: and Natalie Bennett joins us now happy
memories mostly yes it's been a great
four years of no regrets no regrets how
did you decide to step down because we
had a chat I can't remember when it was
exactly but not that long ago and you
said that you hadn't decided we didn't
want to declare I thought you'd made up
your mind then that you were going to
step down but you just didn't want to
make it public was that the case no I
mean basically what I did was I fought
the elections that we had a couple of
weeks ago was entirely focused on that
and then I created some time after that
so it was literally a few days ago that
I made the decision so what made up your
mind well I think I looked at I went
back to what I my proposals that I'd put
forward and I stood for leader four
years ago and I said I wanted to grow
the party I wanted to make him a truly
national party to win our place in the
national debates and I thought I've
achieved those things 1.1 million votes
in the general election being able to
look David Cameron in the eye in those
leader debates and say what are you why
are you so failing to deal with the
issue of Syrian refugees
looking back to sort of on the lighter
moments when I had the yield over the
top of Nigel Faraj and Ed Miliband who
was trying to talk motivate me in the
second leader debate but you know above
all the traveling around the country
I've done visiting local green parties
there's schools more local green parties
around the country than they were we've
of course more than quadrupled the
membership and in the green party
leadership isn't like it is in other
parties it's not a greasy pole where
people are scrambling to the top and
clean there I'm opening up the space for
other people to come forward other
spaces I'm not going away here I'm still
planning very much to be involved are
you interviewing like full time politics
but there's another space in there for
someone else to come forward or other
people to come forward what are you
going to do then or if you say you're
going to still be in full-time politics
I think continue doing a lot of what I'm
doing now I'm very passionate about
education I've spent a lot of time
talking to young people in schools
colleges and universities and they're
very angry and fed up about the way
their education has done real damage to
their lives the level of mental health
issues my first degree was agricultural
science going back to that and looking
about the issues of food growing and a
sustainable food system as leader I've
had to cover everything this will be a
chance to focus a bit more and really
focus on some of the issues that I'm
very passionate about do you think that
was your difficulty if I put it like
that because you yourself admitted that
there were times when it was bruising to
be
particularly from a media perspective
was that impart having to cover so many
areas that perhaps some of which you
didn't feel confident with well I think
one of the problems is you the resources
that the Green Party has even though we
now have more than 60,000 members 4
times the size we were when I was
elected we don't have a you know
billionaire hedge fund owners who are
thinking down the back of the sofa and
finding a few spare millions we still
have a fraction of the resources that
other parties have and so we have to
operate you one of them are things I
said in my message of farewell was
basically saying thank you to all the
Green Party members who volunteered
around the country they've been days
when I've taken my mobile phone and
shoved it into the hand of a sensible
looking person and said media managed me
for the day someone who has no
experience or background at all I
suppose it's not always down to having
expensive back as it is about the person
themselves I mean do you feel you never
felt entirely comfortable in your media
role would that be fair well no I think
it's interesting because um I think I'm
not sort of a lifelong speeding trained
politician and people have sometimes
said they thought I look nervous and I
wasn't you know I I don't I don't get
nervous about these things once I'm in
there in the moment I simply speak about
it in that moment but maybe you know I
haven't got some of the smooth methan
rhythms I haven't got the kind of
smoothness that comes from decades of
doing this and training from a very
young age you know from the kind of
background that produces that look do
you think you need and do you think you
need that to be a sort of successful
sustaining leader of a political party
well I think what we need to see is do
we need to see politics changing and
that addresses much broader issues about
the kind of nature of our media the
nature of the way in which politics is
covered this isn't a football game it's
not about point-scoring what we need to
see is exploration of issues and ideas
and policies and we need to see it not
about personalities but about those
critical things for the future of our
country
